'''''Entoloma hochstetteri''''' is a species of [[mushroom]] found in [[New Zealand]] and [[India]]. The small mushroom is a distinctive all-blue colour, while the [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] have a slight reddish tint from the spores. The blue coloring of the fruit body is due to three [[azulene]] pigments.<ref name="pmid14700203">{{cite journal |doi=10.1039/b202267m |author=Gill M. |title=Pigments of fungi (Macromycetes) |journal=Natural Product Reports |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=615–39 |year=2003 |pmid=14700203}}</ref> Whether ''Entoloma hochstetteri''  is poisonous or not is unknown.

The [[Māori language|Māori]] name for the blue mushroom is '''werewere-kokako''' because the colour is similar to the [[Wattle (anatomy)|blue wattle]] of the [[kōkako]] bird.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/science/9354061/Mushroom-might-yield-major-value |title=Science:Mushroom might yield major value|work= |accessdate=21 Dec 2016}}</ref>

This species was one of six native fungi featured in a set of fungal stamps issued in New Zealand in 2002.<ref>Moss MO, Pegler DN. (2003). Recent stamp issues of fungi from New Zealand. ''Mycologist'' 17:176-178.</ref><ref name="urlWNS: NZ008.02 (Native fungi - Entoloma hochstetteri)">{{cite web |url=http://www.wnsstamps.ch/en/stamps/NZ008.02 |title=WNS: NZ008.02 (Native fungi - ''Entoloma hochstetteri'') |format= |work= |accessdate=2008-11-14}}</ref> 

==Taxonomy==
[[File:Blue mushroom.jpg|thumb|''Enteloma hochstetteri'' is one of the most distinctive mushrooms in the world, is featured on the NZ $50 note and is part of Māori folklore.|left|300x300px]]
The species was first described as ''Hygrophorus hochstetteri'' in 1866 by the Austrian mycologist [[Erwin Reichardt]], before being given its current binomial name in 1962 by [[Greta Stevenson]]. It is named after the German naturalist [[Ferdinand von Hochstetter]].

==Description==
''Entoloma hochstetteri'' has a small delicate [[epigeous]] (above-ground) [[fruiting body]] (basidiocarp) which may be found among moss or leaf litter. The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] may be up to 4 cm (1.4 in) in diameter and conical in shape. The cap color is indigo-blue with a green tint, and is [[wikt:fibrillose|fibrillose]]. The cap margin is striate and rolled inwards. The gill attachment is [[wikt:adnexed|adnexed]] or [[Emarginate gills|emarginate]], gills are thin and 3–5 mm wide, essentially the same color as the cap, sometimes with a yellow tint. The cylindrical [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is up to 5 cm (2 in) long by 0.5 cm thick, fibrillose and stuffed. The [[spore print]] is reddish-pink. The [[spore]]s are 9.9–13.2 by 11.8–13.2 [[micrometre|μm]], tetrahedric in shape, [[hyaline]], smooth and thin-walled. The [[basidium|basidia]] are 35.2–44.2 by 8.8–13.2 µm, club-shaped, [[hyaline]], and with two or four sterigmata.<ref name=Dhancholia>Dhancholia S. (1989). "''Entoloma hochstetteri'' (Agaricales) - a new record from India". ''Current Science'' '''58'''(3): 146–7.</ref>


==Distribution==

''Entoloma hochstetteri'' grows in woodlands of western parts of both the [[North Island|North]] and [[South Island]]s of [[New Zealand]],<ref>Hongo T. (1990). "New and Noteworthy agarics from New Zealand". ''Reports of the Tottori Mycological Institute''. '''28''': 129–34.</ref> where it is associated with ''[[Nothofagus]]'' and ''[[Podocarpus]]'' species. It has also been found in [[India]].<ref name="Dhancholia" />

==Toxicity==
Although many members of the genus ''[[Entoloma]]'' are poisonous, the toxicity of this species is unknown. It has been investigated to see if its blue colouring might be manufactured as a food dye.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gates|first1=Charlie|title=Mushroom might yield major value|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/science/9354061/Mushroom-might-yield-major-value|website=Stuff.co.nz|publisher=Stuff|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref>
